Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CO410201223
Investigation #: 2022C0328011
Complaint Receipt Date: 01/26/2022
Investigation Initiation Date: 01/27/2022
Report Due Date: 03/27/2022
Licensee Name: 17th Circuit Court Family Division
Licensee Address: 1501 Cedar NE
Grand Rapids, MI 495031390
Licensee Telephone #: Unknown
Administrator: Stacy McGinnis, Administrator
Licensee Designee: HueMartin Robinson, Designee
Name of Facility: Kent County Juvenile Detention Center
Facility Address: 1501 Cedar, NE
Grand Rapids, MI 49503-1390
Facility Telephone #: (616) 632-5750
Original Issuance Date: 02/01/1992
License Status: INSPECTED
Effective Date: 10/02/2021
Expiration Date: 10/01/2023
Capacity: 98
Program Type: COURT OPERATED RESIDENTIAL CARE
FACILITY
1

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Youth was denied water and communication with mental health No
services when placed at facility.
Additional Findings No
III. METHODOLOGY
01/26/2022 Special Investigation Intake
2022C0328011
01/27/2022 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
Contact with complaint source
01/28/2022 Inspection Completed On-site
Tour of the facility, interviews with youth and staff
01/28/2022 Contact - Document Received
Reviewed Youth A's file
01/28/2022 Contact - Telephone call made
Phone call with Youth A's probation officer
01/28/2022 Contact - Telephone call made
Phone call attempted to Youth A and voicemail was left
01/28/2022 Contact - Face to Face
Pre exit with Assistant Superintendent of Detention due to Chief
Administrator being on leave
02/01/2022 Contact - Telephone call made
Phone call attempted to Youth A. Voicemail left requesting a
phone call back
02/02/2022 Contact - Document Received
Network 180 policy, Juvenile Rights policy, and Resident
Handbook
ALLEGATION:
Youth was denied water and communication with mental health services when
placed at facility.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews:
Youth A was attempted to be interviewed via phone on January 28, 2022, and
February 1, 2022 but there was no answer. This consultant left a voicemail each
time and did not receive a phone call back. This consultant verified the phone
number with Youth A’s Probation Officer, and he verified it was Youth A’s mother’s
phone number.
2

Probation Officer was interviewed via phone on January 28, 2022. Probation
Officer of Youth A reported Youth A was in the detention facility for only a short
period of time. Probation Officer reported due to that short period of time he did not
visit her in the dentition facility. Probation Officer reported when he has spoken with
Youth A, she did not bring up any of these concerns to him directly. Probation Officer
reported he is working with Youth A’s mother to help with her reported stomach
issues. Probation Officer reported he has worked with this detention facility and has
not had any concerns with the treatment the youth are being provided.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on January 28, 2022. Staff 1
reported her roll at the detention center is the Network 180 liaison. She reported she
is the person that will connect youth with mental health services if needed. Staff 1
stated once a youth is admitted into the facility, she meets with the youth within the
first 24 hours. She will complete a risk assessment and go over coping skills during
that meeting with the youth. Staff 1 reported Youth A was admitted into the facility
during the evening on December 13, 2021, and she met with Youth A at 10:00am on
December 14, 2021. Staff 1 reported when she met with Youth A, she denied any
mental health concerns and had complaints of stomach issues that were being cared
for by the medical team. Staff 1 reported she explained to Youth A what her role was
and offered journals and books to Youth A. Staff 1 reported during the time Youth A
was at the facility there were no emergent Network 180 consultants or requests for
consults.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on January 28, 2022.
Supervisor reported he was present when Youth A was admitted into detention. He
reported Youth A complained of stomach issues and due to her history reported by
her mother the team made sure Youth A met with the nurse right away. Supervisor
reported that he did not get any reports of Youth A requesting mental health
treatment during her stay. Supervisor reported when a youth is admitted into
detention, they meet with Network 180 within 24 hours and confirmed Youth A
completed this meeting. Supervisor reported if a youth or staff member ever need
mental health assistance, staff will call on their walkie talkies to request for a mental
health support. Supervisor reported youth in detention are provided three meals a
day and a snack. Supervisor noted Youth A was provided all meals and she refused
on meal due stomach issues. Supervisor noted this was documented within Youth
A’s file. Supervisor was asked what happens if a youth requests water when they
are in their rooms and Supervisor reported they have access to a sink in their room
with running water and can also ask staff. Supervisor also explained due to COVID-
19 protocols, youth that are admitted into detention must spend their first couple of
days in isolation pending test results. This causes some of the genders to be mixed
on the unit, but each room is a single room. Supervisor noted when a youth is
changing in their rooms, there is a window to close so that peers cannot look into
another youth’s room.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on January 28, 2022. Staff 2
reported she worked with Youth A during her time at detention. Staff 2 reported the
3

only complaint Youth A had was about her stomach and the team made sure she
was able to speak to the nurse when needed. Staff 2 reported Youth A never asked
her for any mental health support. Staff 2 reported if that was to have happened, she
would have called for Network 180 support over the walkie talkies. Staff 2 reported
Youth A was provided meals that included drinks during mealtime. She reported
Youth A had no complaints about needing water and noted Youth A had access to a
sink in her room if she needed water. Staff 2 reported youth can also ask staff for
water at any time as well, but Youth A never requested any.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on January 28, 2022. Youth
B reported he feels well taken care of at the detention center by the staff. Youth B
reported that he can meet with Network 180 when he needs to. He reported that
Staff 1 will do check ins with him. Youth B reported he can ask staff to meet with
Network 180 at any time and they will make the request over their walkie talkies.
Youth B reported the food was decent and that he is able to get three meals a day
plus snacks. Youth B was asked what happens if in the middle of the night he gets
thirsty what does he do. Youth B explained he can get water out of the sink in his
room and that most youth do that at the detention center. Youth B reported he can
make phone calls on scheduled days and can put in requests to contact his attorney
and probation officer when needed. Youth B reported the only thing he would
change about detention is how COVID-19 put harder restrictions due to lower
staffing and youth needing to quarantine.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on January 28, 2022. Youth
C reported he has been at the detention facility for the past nine months. He
reported the staff at the facility treat him well and show respect towards all the youth.
Youth C reported he has been able to gain access to Network 180 services when he
needs it. Youth C said this past month his grandfather had passed away and
Network 180 was able to help him cope with that loss. Youth C said the facility
provides decent food. He reported if you make it to certain goals, you are able to get
treats like ordering out pizza. Youth C was asked what happens if he gets thirsty in
the middle of the night what does he do. Youth C reported he will drink water from
the sink within his room. Youth C reported he is also able to call staff over the
intercom in his room at any time if he needs something. Youth C reported he could
not think of time where staff did not respond to him. Youth C reported the main thing
he doesn’t like about the detention facility is that he wants to be able to talk to family
members more frequently. Youth C reported he is able to call his family every
Tuesday and Saturday, but he wishes that he could do it every day.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on January 28, 2022. Staff 3
reported she did not work with Youth A when she was at the facility. Staff 3 was able
to explain if a youth is requesting for Network 180 services the staff are to call that in
over the walkie talkie so that the youth can be seen. If it is a crisis situation, Staff 3
reported they will call the on-shift supervisor for support and to make sure the youth
have support needed as soon as possible. Staff 3 reported upon admission each
youth is provided a handbook about the facility and how they can request things.
4

Staff 3 reported youth always have access to running water within their rooms
through their sinks. Staff 3 reported youth can fill out slips of paper to be in contact
with their probation officer at any time.
Tour Observation:
A tour of the facility occurred on January 28, 2021. The unit was clean and in
good condition. The three different rooms that Youth A stayed in during her time at
Kent County Detention were viewed. Each room had an operating sink and toilet.
The sink was able to provide hot and cold water. Each room also had a working
intercom system within it, so the youth have access to ask staff for request if
needed. Outside of each of the rooms there is a slider over the window so that no
peers can look into the room if a youth is changing.
Documents Reviewed:
 Youth A’s Case File from Kent County Detention Facility- Youth A’s file notes
she was admitted into the facility on December 13, 2021, at 6:30pm and was
released from the facility on December 15, 2021, at 4:44pm. The file contains
notes that show staff completing fifteen-minute bed checks and notes of youth
complaining of stomach pains and staff sought medical attention. File notes
Youth A met with Network 180 on December 14, 2021, at 10:03am and there
were no mental health concerns noted during that time. Throughout the file
there was no mental health requests or concerns noted. The file notes Youth
A was provided food and refused to eat dinner on December 14, 2021,
because Youth A complained of stomach pains. During that time the nurse
was contacted.
 Psychiatric Provider Initial Evaluation- Youth A completed an initial evaluation
with psychiatrist at the facility on December 15, 2021, at 10:15 am. During
this evaluation, Youth A reported being anxious because she was in detention
and overall feeling fine.
 Youth A’s Medical File from Kent County Detention Facility- The file notes
Youth A was able to meet with medical team on seven different occasions
due to complaints of stomach issues. The facility was able to meet Youth A’s
needs by providing medication when needed. The file notes Youth A has a
history with GI Issues and has an appointment with a Gastroenterologist that
month.
 Network 180 Policy- This policy outlines the role of Network 180 and their role
to review all “new” admissions and involved in all incident reports. When a
resident requests to see Network 180 Youth Specialists notify them via radio
that a resident is requesting a visit. The Unit letter is given. i.e., “A resident
on Unit Fox is requesting to see a therapist.” Network 180 will either proceed
to the unit or indicate that they received the transmission and will be there
following their current session. The policy notes that if at anytime the on-site
Network 180 clinician is not present, the Shift Supervisor must contact Access
Center through Network 180.
5

 Resident Handbook- This handbook is given to each resident upon admission to the
detention. The handbook explains how a resident gets their medical and counseling
needs met. It also explains the rules of meals and the roles of staff. Youth A’s case
file notes she received the resident handbook on December 13, 2021.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.10149 Programs and services.
(2) A facility shall provide or make available the following
minimum programs and services to residents:
(c) Counseling.
(f) Food services.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in compliance as they provided mental
health services, food and water, and medical services to
residents. Through reviewing Youth A’s file and interviews with
staff that worked with Youth A it was noted that she was
provided medical, mental health and food services.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend no change to the license status of this court operated facility.
February 3, 2022
_____________________________________
Cathrine Raftery Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
February 3, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
